100: Control Magic.author: SkyknightXi
100: Control Magic.text_parsed:
Interesting note: Early on, artists weren't actually given details on what their commissioned cards actually DID. Or at least, not all that much on what they did. Thus, you can see why Willich painted the picture he did; he was thinking that by "Control Magic", they were intending not a spell that controls others, but a means to control SPELLS, like the sorceror in the art is containing another spell in some fashion.

@Guest57443454: Except that it was displaced by Abduction and the slightly more expensive Persuasion. In aura form, the metric is now a little more expensive. You still have Sower of Temptation, which adds in a 2/2 flyer, but being a creature, she's easier to dispatch...

You gained a big hasty creature!!! Plus the name of this card is Control Magic this name is misleading because you aren't taking a sorcery or instant card you are actually Controlling a creature. 101: Copy Artifact.author: A3Kitsune
101: Copy Artifact.text_parsed:
This card racks up a lot of firsts, most of them not getting a second until years later, and for some of them it's still the only.
First Artifact Enchantment. First Enchantment Creature (sometimes). First Enchantment that can tap. First Enchantment where it matters wether it's tapped or not. First Legendary Enchantment (again, only sometimes and not for long. The new Legendary rule made this useful). First Enchantment Land (again, sometimes). First Colorless Enchantment. First Artifact that had colored mana in it's casting cost.
101: Copy Artifact.text_posted:

104: Drain Power.author: Elvoran
104: Drain Power.text_parsed:
@Guest57443454

It reads:
Target player activates a mana ability of each land he or she controls. Then put all mana from that player's mana pool into yours.

If you respond by tapping all your lands in response the mana goes to the mana pool. Which will then be drained afterwards.

The only option you have is if you have lands that can produce mana in other ways, such as either Green or White mana. You decide whether to tap it for either colour, but bottom line is that the mana will go to the caster of the spell

@Hand_Bannana

Then nothing.
Dark Depths doesn't have a mana ability which is what Drain Power checks for. It doesn't tap.

105: Feedback.author: Equinox523
105: Feedback.text_parsed:
Part of blue's early color pie was victory by tiny pinpricks. Cards like this, Erosion, Psychic Venom and Prodigal Sorceror lent themselves to the strategy of slow bits of damage adding up to eventually overwhelm the opponent, combined with powerful mana denial like Mana Short, Drain Power, Stasis and Power Sink.

Blue has always been a versatile color, and eventually Wizards just stopped printing these kinds of spells in favor of more interesting and aggressive strategies. But to know how we got here, it's always important to remember past design, both good and bad.
105: Feedback.text_posted:
Part of blue's early color pie was victory by tiny pinpricks.  Cards like this, [autocard]Erosion[/autocard], [autocard]Psychic Venom[/autocard] and [autocard]Prodigal Sorceror[/autocard] lent themselves to the strategy of slow bits of damage adding up to eventually overwhelm the opponent, combined with powerful mana denial like [autocard]Mana Short[/autocard], [autocard]Drain Power[/autocard], [autocard]Stasis[/autocard] and [autocard]Power Sink[/autocard].

Blue has always been a versatile color, and eventually Wizards just stopped printing these kinds of spells in favor of more interesting and aggressive strategies.  But to know how we got here, it's always important to remember past design, both good and bad.

109: Lifetap.author: CorkBulb

Oldschool green hate. Huh.

This is one of the very few blue life gaining cards. This can get you huge amounts of life each turn, assuming it doesn't get removed. Green has always been known for its enchantment removal. Although the flavor of this card feel black to me.

Because it's limited to green decks, it's useful only as a sideboard card, unless you run it with green yourself. It's awfully situational.

3/5

112: Mahamoti Djinn.author: nammertime
112: Mahamoti Djinn.text_parsed:
@Guest: This was considered 'overpowered' because it was so big, had evasion and no drawbacks for a 'cheap' cost. Serra Angel and Sengir Vampire both cost 1 mana less and were 4/4s, while Shivan Dragon cost the same, had firebreathing, but toughness that could still be overcome with this card.

It's just that with today's power creep (eg Baneslayer Angel), most old creatures don't seem so powerful anymore. I mean, c'mon, they even made a whackload of vanilla gold legends because they didn't want to go overboard on creatures...

Anyway, despite what I just mentionned, this is still a good card.

115: Phantasmal Forces.author: Equinox523
115: Phantasmal Forces.text_parsed: This is actually not a terrible creature in a lot of games, though I prefer Phantom Monster in most situations. It's playable in limited and provides 4 power with evasion for 4 mana, which can end a game in short order if your opponent has few blockers or removal - and trade with threats like Serra Angel and Sengir Vampire. Blue was the "air force" color in early Magic, and with a swarm of Flying Men, Phantom Monster, Air Elemental and Mahamoti Djinn protected by countermagic, you could really put some damage on the board and remove everything that posed a threat. Unstable Mutation also addressed this creature's defensive deficiencies, making it really hard to kill - especially if your opponent was tiptoeing around your countermagic.
115: Phantasmal Forces.text_posted: This is actually not a terrible creature in a lot of games, though I prefer [autocard]Phantom Monster[/autocard] in most situations.  It's playable in limited and provides 4 power with evasion for 4 mana, which can end a game in short order if your opponent has few blockers or removal - and trade with threats like [autocard]Serra Angel[/autocard] and [autocard]Sengir Vampire[/autocard].  Blue was the "air force" color in early [i]Magic[/i], and with a swarm of [autocard]Flying Men[/autocard], [autocard]Phantom Monster[/autocard], [autocard]Air Elemental[/autocard] and [autocard]Mahamoti Djinn[/autocard] protected by countermagic, you could really put some damage on the board and remove everything that posed a threat.  [autocard]Unstable Mutation[/autocard] also addressed this creature's defensive deficiencies, making it really hard to kill - especially if your opponent was tiptoeing around your countermagic.

119: Power Leak.author: Equinox523
119: Power Leak.text_parsed:
Back in the day Blue had this strange theme of killing you with little pinpricks, punishing you with little packets of 1 or 2 damage, or tapping your resources, every turn. Psychic Venom, Prodigal Sorcerer, Erosion and Feedback, along with this card, annoyed players when used with Drain Power, Mana Short, Power Sink and of course Mana Drain. These abilities have since moved to black and red.

Blue's methodical kill was annoying to play against, and compromised your opponents' ability to play freely. However, I think Wizards soon realized that these tactics were too slow to keep up with the other colors. For this reason, blue's win conditions have switched to milling, and big flying creatures. After all, they do seem to work better than little conditional and narrow cards like this, which are cute, but are awful in terms of mana curve (especially in the color of counterspells).

These abilities have since moved to black and red.

After all, they do seem to work better than little conditional and narrow cards like this, which are cute, but are awful in terms of mana curve (especially in the color of counterspells).

11: Cyclopean Tomb.author: Mode
11: Cyclopean Tomb.text_parsed:
Yes and no, UNBAN_SHAHRAZAD.
On one hand, this card was likely often played without paying any mana, thinking that a card with no cost could be played for free just like a land card.
On the other hand, according to the current rules, cards without mana cost couldn't be cast at all (e.g. like Evermind or Lotus Bloom)
I kind of like that Alpha misprint, although i'm glad this did only happen to this card (and Orcish Oriflamme given that we're talking about misprinted mana cost in general)- although it got fixed in Beta, players which only knew about the Alpha version likely still played it wrong.

122: Psionic Blast.author: Cyberium
122: Psionic Blast.text_parsed: Many people wonder why Psionic Blast is consider more powerful than Char. The answer is simple. Blue, by tradition, isn't the color of aggression. It's on the other side of Red and Green and thus were designed to be more passive and controlling. Psionic Blast is one of the exceptions where planeswalkers could do direct damage to kill a creature or opponent. Combine with other blue control cards, PB is very dangerous, compare to Char is already in a damage-abundant color. Last but not least, there are also way fewer creatures with protection from blue than red.

127: Spell Blast.author: OmegaSerris
127: Spell Blast.text_parsed:
I agree with you, Equinox523, but I have to make one correction.

It does not counter spells for only unless they also paid 0 into . On the stack, the CMC of those spells is their printed cost ( for Fireball, for example.) PLUS what the controller paid into . So using Fireball again, if it was set to do 5 damage, you have to pay to counter it. Fireball's 'additional targets' ability doesn't count to the CMC though. Everywhere else, Fireball has the CMC of 1, yes. But on the stack, that isn't true.
127: Spell Blast.text_posted:
I agree with you, Equinox523, but I have to make one correction. 

It does not counter [X] spells for only [U] unless they also paid 0 into [X]. On the stack, the CMC of those spells is their printed cost ([R] for [autocard]Fireball[/autocard], for example.) PLUS what the controller paid into [X]. So using Fireball again, if it was set to do 5 damage, you have to pay [5U] to counter it. Fireball's 'additional targets' ability doesn't count to the CMC though. Everywhere else, Fireball has the CMC of 1, yes. But on the stack, that isn't true.

127: Spell Blast.author: Ibn_Shisha
127: Spell Blast.text_parsed:
I don't understand the low rating here. Granted, Counterspell is the king, but this one, especially in the late game, is much more useful than the higher-rated Power Sink.

@Equinox:
Generally in the late game, there will be quite a bit of mana out. You're unlikely to have a problem casting Spell Blast, especially on cards from this era. However, keeping enough mana open to Power Sink someone in way that kills not just their spell but also their turn by tap out, kind of restricts your own play as well. Holding on to that Power Sink and enough mana to make it a late game threat can give you card disadvantage.

That's what a was getting at.

Anyway, they're both strictly worse than Force Spike.

131: Time Walk.author: Urto
131: Time Walk.text_parsed:
I like Time Walk because I think that, as a standalone, it is the most clearly broken of the Power Nine. Black Lotus is obviously the best overall, but even that can't do anything on its own. It must synergize with the power of other cards (such as the oft-referenced Channel and Fireball combo).

Time Walk, even if not quite the greatest, is singularly and distinctly overpowered of its own accord, and with the power of cards today, even an amatuer player can recognize this glaring balance issue at first glance. It truly is testament to how casual of a game Magic was originally intended to be.

132: Timetwister.author: Pontiac
132: Timetwister.text_parsed:
to all of you who are stating that Timetwister is overhyped, I highly doubt your ever owned and played with one. In a deck with Windfall, Wheel of Fortune, and Memory Jar, with the rest of the power and other fast mana like Vaults, Sol Ring and Dark Rituals this card spanks people, you cast it with ease. I spent many a first turns droping a blue dual and two moxes, or a mox and a sol ring or Mana Crypt or whatever, I then cast Twister refill my hand and possibly do more right away with other moxen floating around, at worst case I drew force of wills, counters and drains, I still had control.

at 2U to cast Timetwister can ruin someones day, I remember watching an opponent mulligan his hand down to 5 cards to get his combo in his hand, so I Timetwistered and he folded, true story.

132: Timetwister.author: DarthParallax
132: Timetwister.text_parsed:
Lotus Petal still got Banned.
Mox Diamond still made it to the Vault.
The Artifact Lands were kind of like Moxen, actually, and they got Banned,
and even without Affinity would have still comboed with Tolarian Academy.
PONDER is too good, let alone Brainstorm,let alone Ancestral Vision etc. etc.
Time Warp appears to be 'safe', but still great in any deck that plays Blue.

Time Reversal? Of the Power 9, this one's cost was increased the least for its 'Modern' version, and yet remains the weakest doing exactly the same thing for just 1U more when Time Walk's effect or Draw 3 cards will cost you at least 3-5 times as much as the Power versions. I'm not saying this thing isn't good-it's one of the best cards in the game. Just that of all the Power 9, mana cost seems to matter the most on this one.

133: Twiddle.author: kitsunewarlock
133: Twiddle.text_parsed: A classic. It protects you from damage, gives you a blocker, lets you use that creature's tap ability twice, ramps your mana with cards like Tolarian Academy, Sol Ring or just Tron. It protects you from counter-spells by tapping out your opponent's last island, you can put it on Scepter to get an Icy Manipulator on crack. It lets you use your artifact again and de-activates artifacts like Winter Orb or Howling Mine. There have been many variations of this card, many of which are a tad stronger. But Twiddle will always maintain its status as the first.

135: Vesuvan Doppelganger.author: Hambot
135: Vesuvan Doppelganger.text_parsed:
The coolest think you can do with a doppleganger is to get it to copy itself. Next turn, the ability triggers twice, so you keep selecting itself. 2,4,8,16 instances of the triggered ability over subsequent turns. Then with a morphling in play, you can switch to something like a prodigal sorcerer, switch back to morphling, pay U, untap, switch to prodigal sorcerer as many times as you can.

The most practical sort of target is a multiplayer beater like a pristine angel, then you can turn it into the biggest fattest creature in play when you are ready to win.

136: Volcanic Eruption.author: Joseph_Leito
136: Volcanic Eruption.text_parsed:
An interesting case of the errata slightly changing the play of the card. Given the original wording, if an opponent had three mountains in play and you cast this card with four mana for X, it would have destroyed the mountains and done 4 damage. Now that they equated the damage directly to the mountains destroyed, that's not possible.

It doesn't change how good the card is, because paying that much for a bit of extra burn would be dumb. Just interesting.

Apparently this had the more intuitive "destroy X, deal X" template until Revised, when a minor interaction with Consecrate Land and Pyramids was inexplicably introduced.

This would make perfect sense as a red card that destroyed Islands. Heck, Active Volcano already relies on that flavor!

It's even more surprising that this never had a red version when you consider all of the mirrored 2-card cycles in Alpha, like Red Elemental Blast/Blue Elemental Blast and Fire Elemental/Water Elemental.

141: Berserk.author: gman92
141: Berserk.text_parsed:
When I first saw Berserk, it was in a card shop, and it was an Alpha or Beta one. I read it like I would read any other card, not being from the age of Alpha. "Until end of turn, target creature's power doubles and it gains trample ability. If it attacks, target creature is destroyed at end of turn. I was like "That's pretty good. They had to give Green something back then." Even reading it wrong, and thinking it was more ridiculous than it is, I thought it was right at home in the set it was first released in. A testament to the power of Alpha/Beta/Unlimited.
5/5
141: Berserk.text_posted:
When I first saw Berserk, it was in a card shop, and it was an Alpha or Beta one. I read it like I would read any other card, not being from the age of Alpha. A testament to the power of Alpha/Beta/Unlimited.

142: Birds of Paradise.author: liir007
142: Birds of Paradise.text_parsed:
Card of the Day - Friday, March 29, 2002
The Birds have been one of the staples of the game since it began, but they were created as an afterthought. Their art was originally supposed to be for Tropical Island, but the bird was too prominent. So Richard Garfield created a card just for the art, and it ended up being the most versatile mana-producing creature ever.
--Also the creature type was 'Mana Birds', modern versions are just 'Bird'
142: Birds of Paradise.text_posted:

150: Force of Nature.author: Mode
150: Force of Nature.text_parsed:
I love the old wording which rants about what happens when you fail to pay the cost. Neither reminder text nor mana symbols, now that is classical oldschool magic :D
These days it's not quite what it used to be though, since there are preferable timmy finishers, but hey, look at it: An artwork with a bulky creature, quadruple-green casting and upkeep cost, 8 intimidating points of toughness and power (which you're going to take note of if you don't treat this thing right), and most of all: "Summon Force" - can it get any more timmy?
150: Force of Nature.text_posted:

151: Fungusaur.author: mpawliuk
151: Fungusaur.text_parsed:
Note that he will survive your pestilence (if you are smart about it), but your opponent can kill him with pestilence.

1- Activate Pestilence once.
2- One damage to Fungusaur.
3- Fungu's ability goes on the stack.
4- Activate Pestilence and upon resolution another damage goes on Fungu and he dies as a state-based effect, before counters go on.

Of course, if you control pestilence you can just let the counter go on first, then activate pestilence again.

153: Giant Growth.author: DarthParallax
153: Giant Growth.text_parsed:
I'm going to comment on Every Card in Gatherer this week :)

This card is awesome because of all the Boons, it is the absolute best for being reprinted, since it has good Limited play. Wizards will design things in the future that are better than this card, but I don't think they ever plan on OBSOLETing it. They may make 2 mana +5/+5's in the far future, but I think we are always going to be able to cast Giant Growth in Standard.

I think a good distinction to make between True Power Creep and ...Power Penduluming....is 'will there ever be a day when we no longer use Giant Growths?' That day will be the day Magic is Fully Power Creeped.

153: Giant Growth.author: Equinox523
153: Giant Growth.text_parsed:
The iconic green pump spell, against which all others will be compared for eternity. It just teaches you so much about the game, both offensively and defensively, by giving you that extra power to knock out an opposing creature, allowing your own creatures to survive lethal damage, or forcing through that extra bit of damage to win the game. It teaches you timing, patience, and resource management, because sometimes you have to hold it instead of playing it even though you have mana open. Sometimes you need to save up mana expressly to be able to play it in response to things.

As you get better at the game, so too does your use of this card evolve with your understanding. If your opponent knows you have some in your deck, they will sometimes play cautiously because they know you have it, allowing you to play mind games and bluff having it when you don't. Combined with discard and control elements, you can save multiples in your hand for a fatal attack. You'll discover synergies for it. And it's never going to be completely useless, as long as you play green, and you have creatures.

All in all, this is the one card in the Alpha boon cycle that Wizards got completely right.

15: Gauntlet of Might.author: CorkBulb
15: Gauntlet of Might.text_parsed:
This is a killer (obviously) in a red deck. Best if it is mono-red. It also fits the theme of red very nicely, as it also causes your opponent to get the bonus too, which would be inducing chaos. Makes getting that lethal damage with disintegrate or fireball much easier, not to mention huge mana acceleration. You could have 10 red mana on turn 5! I think the cost vs effect is very balanced, especially for Alpha days.

4.5/5

"All creatures able to block target creature must do so. If a creature has the ability to block more than one creature, Lure does not prevent this. If there is more than one attacking creature with Lure, defender may choose which of them each defending creature blocks."
Oracle:
"All creatures able to block enchanted creature do so."

I love old cards.

167: Lure.author: Pongdok
167: Lure.text_parsed: This is the original green alpha strike card. With this on an Uthden Troll, or some other weenie with regeneration, you were free to swing away for the rest of the game. Normally would only take another turn or two, though. My favourites for this are Elven Warhounds and Tolarian Entrancer. This is way better than Taunting Elf and its cretinous, inbred cousin, Prized Unicorn, which could really have used haste. 5/5

16: Glasses of Urza.author: Kryptnyt
16: Glasses of Urza.text_parsed:
The only reason this kind effect is not worth it in competitive play is because it is easy enough to know what your opponent is playing, so its not worth a card. In casual, however, your opponent could be playing just about anything. Knowing what is coming can easily hand you games.
In a blue deck, though, I kind of like Telepathy more, at least for multiplayer... they have to see each other's hands, and so they will play differently than they would normally with that information.
Current standard play uses Gitaxian Probe because it is almost free and replaces itself, plus can make your Snapcaster Mage cantrip. Hand information is a small bonus there.

170: Regrowth.author: jonrds
170: Regrowth.text_parsed:
Treasured Find is quite a bit worse than this for 2 reasons. First, it requires 2 colors, which is much harder to generate with lotuses and second, it exiles itself, killing any combos with other graveyard recursion.

If you want to see a better example of how this effect has dropped in power look at eternal witness. Definitely agree that this is somewhat overrated at the moment though. That said, what makes it good is the same thing that makes snapcaster mage good, it isnt just a card, its whatever card you need at the moment. Can definitely see why that effect is more appreciated in formats with more powerful cards.

Still, Vulpy's dream of catching the big half-pipe waves off Pisco Beach seemed closer than ever.[/i]

179: Wall of Brambles.author: DrJack
179: Wall of Brambles.text_parsed: See, this is what art looks like. That large white space in the corner is "negative space", as artists call it. It gives perspective and balance. New art (mostly) doesn't have negative space, just ultra-saturated colors all over the place, like some kind of visual MSG to stimulate your optical nerves to exhaustion. I could see new kids looking at this art and feeling their minds being blown by all that blank white space, like it was some kind of deafening silence in contrast to the extremely active, angular, Tom-Cruise-action-thriller photographs they've been churning out for the last decade.

183: War Mammoth.author: Guest392185251
183: War Mammoth.text_parsed:
A mammoth walks down the street
He says why am I errata'd in the middle now
Why am I errata'd in the middle
Of the creature type of my card
I need an Adaptive Automaton
And I'm no Uncle Istvan
Don't want to end up an elephant
In an Elephant Graveyard
Boneknitter Boneknitter
Heals Hollow Dogs in the moonlight
Farrel's Zealot lost his zeal
Mistform Ultimus and Fire-belly
Said get this mammoth away from me
You know I don't find this Brushwagg amusing anymore

Chorus:
If you'll be my bodyguard
I can be your long lost mount
I can call you Vetty
And Vetty when you call me
You can call Mi'cha

A dwarf walks down the street
He says why am I short of enlistments
Got a short little list of enlistments
Wo Shadowmoor's nights are so long
Where's my Matron and incendiaries
What if we mine here
Who will fetch my rutabagas
Now that my rutabaga fetchers are gone, gone
They ducked back down the digestive tract
Of some roly-poly little Femeref pestridder
All along along
There were battle cries and avalanches
There were slaves and emancipations

Chorus
Flute solo

A mammoth walks down the street
It's a street in a strange world
Maybe it's the Un-World
Or maybe it's his first time online
He doesn't speak the language
He holds no rarity
He sees a foreign card
He is surrounded by nouns, nouns
"Creature" on the type line
Enchantment hyphen aura
He looks around, around
He sees addictive ink in the R&D's Lair
Reflecting to infinity
He says Amen and Hallelujah

Chorus

If you be my bodyguard.
I can call you Vetty.
Fade Away

Excerpt from the Wikipedia entry:
In You Can Call Mi'cha, Paul Simon touches on the theme of the emammothculation faced by middle-aged Magic players. The first verse reflects the titular character's frustration with wanting to keep his unique identity instead of being lumped in with other pachyderms.
In the chorus, he finds solace in sharing his experience with another alpha card.
The second verse describes Dwarven Recruiter's frustration with how Dwarves never got the support that Goblins did, appearing briefly as recently as Shadowmoor block only to never be heard from again. The highlights of the Dwarves glorious history are touched on briefly.
Finally, we return to the titular character in a modern magic environment. Although he is confused at first, he finds salvation upon discovering the "combo" of R&D's Secret Lair and Infinite Reflections, allowing him to maintain his mammoth-hood and meet others just like him!

187: Chaoslace.author: SkyknightXi
187: Chaoslace.text_parsed: Let's remember again: Vorthos was the main audience intended when the game came out, and they had no real reason to imagine Spike's existence (they didn't know the game would be so popular, remember?). The reason the laces are rare is simply because they have, by the original set's lights, a VERY strange ability. Changing a spell or permanent's color is, well, extremely meta, in the same fashion as Sleight of Mind and Magical Hack. Putting them in rare can be thought of as an attempt to ensure that none of the nuts and bolts--the cards you DID find at common and uncommon--would be drowned out by the arcane oddballs.
187: Chaoslace.text_posted: Let's remember again: Vorthos was the main audience intended when the game came out, and they had no real reason to imagine Spike's existence (they didn't know the game would be so popular, remember?). 18: Howling Mine.author: Equinox523
18: Howling Mine.text_parsed:
While on it's face it looks like this grants the same utility to both players, in reality it does not: unless you have an extra turn, your opponent gets a draw phase before you do, meaning they get the benefit before you. While many decks will be perfectly fine with this, it will also mean that your opponent may draw answers to your threats quickly.

It's worth noting that this can be quite synergistic with Black Vise if your opponent has a slow deck, dealing colorless damage or forcing your opponent to overcommit to their board, making them make decisions that might otherwise be inadvisable.

1: Ankh of Mishra.author: Couchman
1: Ankh of Mishra.text_parsed:
Card --

The Ankh of Mishra is an ok card, although the main problem is that if you play it too early you suffer just as much as your opponents. You may think you have enough lands, until you want to cast more spells in a turn! In my early days, I built some kind of burn deck with this in it. I really could've used that last lightning bolt. It has its uses, but overall I'd rather just use something else. Even in Land destruction!

3.5/5

1: Ankh of Mishra.author: DarthParallax
1: Ankh of Mishra.text_parsed:
Commenting on Every Card this Weekend! :D And commenting on Alpha cards really is fun. I need to eventually Draft Alpha. heck I don't care if you take the Power out-- Alpha Magic is just Cool and Fun even without $1000 dollar cards! :O

This is an interesting concept of card. It certainly FEELS like a really Egyptian Curse, which is neat. I like that even though we've never had an explicitly Egyptian Block, there's a lot of cards in Magic that have an Egyptian/Dr. Fate kind of feel to them :)

The problem with this card is that being of low converted mana cost, it encourages you to play it early, and that does hurt you much, and you really should never play this in Multiplayer.

I think {3} is a great number to cast this for, since that could come down early if you have a plan to get around the two-edgedness, but if you don't have enough support and want to throw this down to stop ALL the lands and rely on the lands you have in play, then it's still castable early enough to hurt people but you don't feel like a putz for waiting til turn 5 to cast it.

I think that it would also just be neat and cool if this was able to sacrifice itself to gain you 2 life, as a one-shot way to make it better for you than your opponent. We've come along way and realized that Wrath of God is very good, and making things too one-sided like with Balance is very bad, but most cards should clearly sit somewhere in the middle and basically be something to give you advantage if you play it. As is, this doesn't clearly give you advantage so much as Declare a New Rule for everyone that accelerates the game to end faster. Cards like that are...alright, but usually making tiny tweaks so that the effects aren't REALLY even is a Good Thing, if you don't go overboard and make lots of Balances.

I want this to feel like an ARTIFACT, not a Red, White, or Black card, if possible. 3 CMC plus the sac clause would make it less like a White New Rule card, less like a Red All In card, and the lifegain would help keep it feeling more Artifact-y than Black :)

200: Fork.author: Equinox523
200: Fork.text_parsed:
Introducing the Fork Table.

Shock: for 4 damage.
Lightning Bolt: for 6 damage.
Flame Javelin: for 8 damage.
Fireblast: for 8 damage.
(often for 8 damage)
Lava Axe: for 10 damage.
Fireball:
1 point - for 2 damage.
2 points - for 4 damage.
3 points - for 6 damage.
4 points - for 8 damage.
5 points - for 10 damage.
6 points - for 12 damage.
7 points - for 14 damage.
8 points - for 16 damage.
9 points - for 18 damage.
10 points - for 20 damage.

In short, Fork is awesome. I'm glad Twincast was replaced by Reverberate because in-color, this is way better due to red's ability to suddenly win the game via burn.

PS: Some funny stuff as an added bonus:
Wildfire: , Each player sacrifices 8 lands. Wildfire deals 8 damage to each creature.
Inferno: Inferno deals 12 damage to each creature and each player.
Flame Wave: Flame Wave deals 8 damage to target player and each creature he or she controls.

All these are just for red, to give you some idea of how awesome this card is.

201: Goblin Balloon Brigade.author: FooHunter
201: Goblin Balloon Brigade.text_parsed:
> Did people in 1993 think this card made all your goblins fly? Cause that's how it reads.

Not the people I played with. We just laughed everytime I brought it out. Actually there were a number of funky misprints in the Alpha cards. Part of the entertainment was arguing over the interpretation of the cards and the rules. For example, see the original rules on instants and interrupts. I don't think we ever agreed on how interrupts worked before they were removed. WOTC finally straightened out the rules when they tried to write them into a PC game.

202: Goblin King.author: WhereDidItGo
202: Goblin King.text_parsed:
@A3Kitsune: Actually, from what I've heard about the rules during the Alpha/Beta/Revised era, a creature's type line was its type. Thus, Gaea's Liege was considered to be a "Gaea's Liege" but not a "Liege", Uncle Istvan was considered an "Uncle Istvan" but not an "Uncle" nor and "Istvan", and so on.
THE MORE YOU KNOW.
202: Goblin King.text_posted:
@A3Kitsune: Actually, from what I've heard about the rules during the Alpha/Beta/Revised era, a creature's type line [i]was[/i] its type. 211: Manabarbs.author: Ibn_Shisha
211: Manabarbs.text_parsed:
Unfortunately, Power Surge has been made all but pointless since they got rid of mana burn. This card is a decent grinder on its own, though.

@Arglypuff: Please note, while Power Surge damages at the beginning of the upkeep, the land count is at the beginning of the turn. I.e., before untap. With mana burn gone now, if an opponent has Power Surge, just tap all your lands before the end of the turn before yours, thereby having no untapped land at the beginning of your turn, then untap them all, take no damage, draw your card, gtg.

Addendum: Of course, having both out kind of makes that a moot point - damage will be done 1 way or the other.

211: Manabarbs.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
211: Manabarbs.text_parsed: Note the ABU version of this card is more powerful than later printings, as this card only checks to see if a land is tapped. It does not care if the land was tapped to draw mana, and it does not care if the land was tapped by an external effect (e.g., Twiddle).
211: Manabarbs.text_posted: Note the ABU version of this card is more powerful than later printings, as this card only checks to see if a land is tapped. It does not care if the land was tapped to draw mana, and it does not care if the land was tapped by an external effect (e.g., [autocard]Twiddle[/autocard]).

215: Power Surge.author: DrJack
215: Power Surge.text_parsed:
Do you guys actually play with the ridiculous new rules that eliminate mana burn? I refuse to play that way, ever. Not for a tournament, not for casual play. Mana burn was part of the game for nearly 20 years for a reason. It forces players to actually make calculated decisions with their resources. Without mana burn, players can just haphazardly tap their lands for mana in a sloppy manner. Mana burn also makes cards like Black Lotus, Sol Ring, and Mana Drain slightly balanced. Seriously, these cards would actually be considerably more powerful - if you can imagine that - without the threat of mana burn. Is this what we want?

Then we have cards like Mana Vault, Mana Crypt, Mishra's Workshop, and the Urza lands. You have to actually think before tapping this cards - if mana burn exists, as it should.

And finally, there's cards like Power Surge, which were obviously designed with the reality of mana burn in mind. Of course, so was Mana Drain - the threat of mana burn was the only thing keeping it even slightly sane!!

Why the hell did WotC throw mana burn on the scrapheap? My guess is it was to simplify the game yet further, for the Pokemon kids. Just like eliminating interrupts was. They have changed Magic: the Gathering far too many times in its short lifespan. Imagine if chess went through zillions of changes every decade? It wouldn't have lasted several centuries, that's for sure.

If there was ever a chance of this card being antiquated/outdated/made irrelevant, then Jace, the Mind Sculptor forever put those fears to rest, lol.

Blue Elemental Blast is also still going strong, but I don't think it will appreciate as much longevity. 25 Years? 40 Years? 50 Years? One day, it MAY be the case that Red Permanents are not enough of a concern in Legacy or Vintage and the counterspells they already have are sufficient.

I admit, for BEB to not even see sideboard play though, it would probably mean that Red as a Color had somehow become defunct. Of all the colors that could though, Red is the one that actually might. It already is hands down the weakest in Commander. Commander ain't the same as Legacy/Vintage by a mile, but they're more similar to each other than they are to Standard of course.

This card interests me because at the time it was made it was strictly better than another card in Alpha, Hill Giant. Nowadays the Giant tribal cards means that Hill Giant isn't STRICTLY worse, just much worse.

Um. Braid of Fire + Paradox Haze.
Cool, with 4 paradox hazes, I get 5 upkeeps.
Assuming Braid got played the same turn all my Hazes got out, upkeep one, +1 Red, Upkeep 2, +2 red, Upkeep 3, +3 red, upkeep 4, +4 red, upkeep 5, +5 red. 15 red mana = 5 heads :O
Ohwait, I just Doubling Season.
Again, 4 paradox hazes, 4 doublings, and ONE braid of fire. upkeep one, +16 red, upkeep 2, +32 red, upkeep 3, +48 red, upkeep 4, + 66 red, upkeep 5, +82 red. Altogether that is 244 red. And since paying for that head is adding a counter, you add that many counters instead. 244 red mana = 1296 heads and one leftover red mana :O
That's really cool yknow? Also, cool, Fate Transfer to Molten Hydra, to kill enemy.

222: Shivan Dragon.author: Technetium
222: Shivan Dragon.text_parsed: How far they've fallen. When I started playing in the early 90s, Revised had just been released. At the time, this was easily the most valuable card in the set, and the only to be worth nearly $20. The format was really slow then and it allowed for this creature to be a game-winner. Now, it's a little bit under-powered by today's standards, though. Consider the abilities of the Kamigawa dragons (which have the same P/T and CMC) in contrast. And then there's the Thundermaw that totally changes the expectations for a 5 or 6 CMC creature. Great as it once was, the Shivan will probably never see pro use again (well, unless WotC underpowers subsequent sets to make it viable again).

3/4 for {2}{R}{R} with a pretty relevant ability in {R}, can effectively Fling smaller creatures at your opponents face, interestingly enough the ability will destroy the creature at the end of the turn, so it has particularly good interaction with indestructible creatures such as Darksteel Sentinel or Thornling (after increasing it's power by 1 for {G} to make it a 5/3).

I think it would be hilarious to see someone throw a Phage the Untouchable at the either by reducing the toughness of phage (something like Wring Flesh) or increasing the power of Stone Giant (by using something like Giant Growth)

229: Wall of Fire.author: Pumpkin2146
229: Wall of Fire.text_parsed:
DRCCOTD #1: Wall of Fire.

A 0/5 with defender, and the ability to firebreath. This is an interesting card because it doesn't fit very well into the theme of what red is generally trying to do. Red generally wants you dead, right about now. This card really doesn't support that aim from red at all.

As a defensive card as well, this compares poorly to other cards in other colours that do similar things. For example from modern sets, Wall of Frost is a modern take on this card that is much better. Costing 1UU, it is in a colour that is more interested in a defensive creature, and it can "handle" two creatures at once. While Wall of Fire can block and kill things, red doesn't generally want to be doing that. Other recent cards it compares poorly to include Wall Of Omens or Wall of Denial

If Wall Of Fire was printed in a modern set (and it was as recently as M10), I think it would (and it did) be a fringe playable limited card. Something that sometimes makes your decks, but you are never particularly proud to be playing.

230: Wall of Stone.author: allmighty_abacus
230: Wall of Stone.text_parsed:
Perhaps the biggest flaw with the wall creature type is that all walls are bound by the same "can only block 1 creature" rule as other creatures. I mean, if a wall stretches all the way into the horizon in both directions, it's downright unflavorful for the rest of the creatures it can't block to simply walk around it.

If walls aren't ever going to attack (unless you do something crazy like rolling stones or some such), I think it's perfectly reasonable to let them block more than one creature. Very few walls have more than 2 power, and almost all of them have 0. I'm not saying all walls should be able to block all creatures, but maybe just 1 additional creature would be nice and people would actually use walls in non-casual games.

233: Armageddon.author: Werewolf-
233: Armageddon.text_parsed:
Many people consider land destruction to be "unfun," but it's an integral component to Magic in all formats, from Standard all the way to Vintage.

Your mana base is just another resource that you have to protect if you want to win...just as Lightning Bolt zaps your life total and Hymn to Tourach mutilates your hand, land destruction screws up your mana base--and like any other strategy, it has its counter-strategies...if your friend is killing you with massive discard, you'd sideboard in Leyline of Sanctity. If your friend is killing you with Armageddon, you sideboard in Sacred Ground. What's the big deal?

233: Armageddon.author: DarthParallax
233: Armageddon.text_parsed:
12:40 AM

12/24/2012

I'm sending this back in Time in the Mad Hope that someone can save us. I hope someone can save us.

It is Dawn of the Third Day

The ZOMBIES are everywhere, rising from their Ancestral Recalled homelands in Ancient May, the true birthplace of the Mayan Civilzation, one of the 12 districts of the Island Kingdom of the Lord of Atlantis, Zedd. It shockingly rose in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean. The Power Rangers were all killed on the Moon by Mockingbirds that nobody knew How to Kill, because they hadn't seen this:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KevzcHUUKAY
Mockingbirds are like Storm Crows, only 1000 x 1000 x worse.
But we had no Pirates or Ninjas or Literary Devices to save us this time, because Lord Voldemort came back and destroyed all the books in the Library. All the Potterheads committed suicide at this.

Three days and nights' pursuit. No food. No rest. We've given no sign of our location to our hunters but what bare rock can tell. Bare rock is all that survived the nuclear blasts that OBLITERATED the surface. We few, we refugees of Human Civilization, crawled out of our shelters just 24 hours ago to bear witness to the Devastation of an Entire Planet. We are the last hope for Resistance against the Empire. The zombies attacked Washington, DC first and killed everyone doing anything important. There weren't many casualties, but nobody knew what to do, so a Totalitarian Regime was established. It takes Time to set up a Free Nation, but a Hostile Takeover can happen pretty quick, especially when it runs on the popular "Kill All Zombies" platform during a Zombie Apocalypse

The zombies took everything that survived the nuclear holocaust, and burned it. They can't run, but they're on fire, and that's even scarier. I've been keeping this journal in elvish, because I think if any aliens land on our planet, they'll find that easier to read than lolspeak. There aren't even any ***roaches to eat. The zombies burned them all.

I've been making my way from the city of Fredericksburg, VA to New Rishadan Port, in the hopes of finding my lost love. I won't dare use her real name here, in case the KGB track her down through these notes if I'm captured. The KGB are working with the zombies. We think the virus started when they began experimenting on troops in response to the Avengers Initiative. I forgot to mention I'm an Agent of SHIELD. Her codename is Lily, because I'll Always love her.

We're making camp now, in an Abandoned Warehouse district. Wait. That noise. What is it? Oh. No.
Oh NO. The zombies. They are coming! We cannot get out! Drums, in the deep! We cannot get OUT! They ARE COMING!......


This wasn't the End we Deserved. But it was the End we Needed.

APOCALYPSE NOW

234: Balance.author: Guest57443454
234: Balance.text_parsed:
One of the most broken cards ever printed, how this made it to 4th edition is beyond me. discard, LD and removal all for 1W, stupidly powerful.

This was comboed with Zuran Orb for a one-sided Armageddon with the help of artifact mana, with Mox Diamond to create a cheap Mind Twist, and so on...

Although one of the funniest stories about that second combo, printed in the old Inquest, was that somebody dropped down to two cards in his opening hand when he played balance. His opponent promptly dropped three Guerilla Tactics dealing 12 damage on the first turn.

The important thing to say about the Alpha one is, that after a long time of thinking I did not like this strange knight in the art nearly as much as the FTV Angel art for it, I have come around to deciding that my favorite Balance art is the Judge Foil Promo. :O

239: Blue Ward.author: car2n
239: Blue Ward.text_parsed: The pop-art (yet neo-minimalist) etchings of Blue Ward,  liegemen to the Pollackian legacy, question its own raison d'etre. Is it visual tropes? Is it self-conscious (self-mocking/self-loathing) po-mo nombrilisme? Or is it simply (and solely) a stochastic snapshot sans lexical basis? The color ward cycle can best be examined as artistic interventions against the oppressive humor archetype, whereas the unappealingly desperate musings of Dan Frazier's eponymous series are truly indebted to Jenny Holzer’s oeuvre. Or, as Baudrillard and Guillaume so succinctly state, "What is produced with the romantic turn…is…the…play of…masculine hysteria…of …sexual paradigms that once again must be reinserted in the more general and universal context of a change in the paradigms of otherness."

245: Consecrate Land.author: Aquillion
245: Consecrate Land.text_parsed:
Way back during Alpha's development, there was a big argument about how this interacted with Stone Rain.

Specifically, Stone Rain says it destroys the land, while this says the land can't be destroyed. The two cards contradict! And according to the rules, when two cards contradict, the later one takes precedence, meaning that Stone Rain always wins and this card never does anything.

(This led to a rule that a card that prevents something from happening always trumps a card that says it happens.)

245: Consecrate Land.author: DarthParallax
245: Consecrate Land.text_parsed:
this isn't even remotely narrow and people that think it is just don't know how many varieties of Land Based strategies there are:

1. Vintage: Play on your Mishra's Workshop or Tolarian Academy (High Stakes Vintage this works less because it's slow and almost certainly you'd be splashing {W}, not {W} main. Adjusting your deck to be able to cast this more is a GREAT WAY to make such combo decks more fair and fun for Friendly Vintage, and also make your opponents' Strip Mine less devastating, particularly if they are running Crucible of Worlds with it.

2. Legacy/EDH: Whatever your most KEY color fixing land is: A Filter Land, a Shock Land, Reflecting Pool, a Vivid Land, City of Brass: Not as many "Combos" in Legacy based off of a Single Land being absolutely balls-to-the-walls BAHROHKAHN, but Wasteland is still around for everyone not running Blood Moon, and this card would be good because it's good against Wasteland even though it 'dies' to Blood Moon. Doesn't stop everything like Anathemancer, but stops SOME of the LD bleeding, like Armageddon, Jokulhaups, that-kinda-stuff, and attacking your opponents' lands is so good that every card that protects lands, even if it's not "Auto-4-of", IS "Auto-Narrowly-Useful".

3. Modern: Dark Depths? Thespian's Stage? Would combos like this be less ban-worthy if LD playability was increased and consequently the idea of a Land Enchantment protection was less laughable? Picture a different format than we see today, one where something close to Pillage might be heavily played? Oh Yeah. And Inkmoth Nexus, Mishra's Factory (if they changed their minds about Duel Decks' general card legality state? but then further started with just a Demonic Tutor Ban from the cards affected??)

4. Standard, or any FNM Format, or any Pizza Night Magic at any given time with untuned decks: Man Lands, from Zendikar Duals to Mutavault, AND even the Xth Edition ones that are less highly praised but still often used for the heck of it.

Any card that effects lands is a land that impacts the game significantly. The "play 4 of these on your own and then cast Armageddon" route is exctremely rough and crude, AND YET it still sounds pretty attractive to see if I can even just build that deck and save TWO of my lands while destroying ALL of theirs.

Lands are Legit. Heck I didn't even get around to Valakut and even wierder Land interactions. The lists are quite long of the decks that would be happy to see this card.

(I named cards whose interaction with Consecrate Land seemed to me to resemble about the Power Level of the Play that could make an impact there- in some cases I imagined an Alternate Universe of the Format where the cardpools were different than they actually are, but the average "Turn Clock" Power Level of the format was somewhere close to the ballpark of the real world. EVERY single one of these uses is very relevant in Loose EDH, some of these are less feasible to imagine in Higher Powered Formats, like the Man-Duals, but would certainly matter somewhere, like imagine if Man-Duals and this co-existed in Standard: Not good enough for Modern I think, but good enough for Standard Fo Show.)

The basic one-sentence evaluation is that it's a much MUCH Spikier, Narrower, Techier Terra Eternal. Being more castable probably counts more in the long run than not protecting every single one of your lands does, *particularly* for those Vintage Combos. This card probably make Strip Mine and Wasteland fairer to have 4 of either in Vintage-with-Friends (Vintage where everyone has to sideboard against Dredge is different). You probably wouldn't run 8 LD Lands in Vintage anyway because you want to play as few lands as possible because you want your mana curve to be supertight and need more attack points and spell effects than mana to kill As Fast As Cardboard Possible.
245: Consecrate Land.text_posted:
this isn't even remotely narrow and people that think it is just don't know how many varieties of Land Based strategies there are: 

1. Vintage: Play on your [autocard]Mishra's Workshop[/autocard] or [autocard]Tolarian Academy[/autocard] (High Stakes Vintage this works less because it's slow and almost certainly you'd be splashing {W}, not {W} main. Adjusting your deck to be able to cast this more is a GREAT WAY to make such combo decks more fair and fun for Friendly Vintage, and also make your opponents' [autocard]Strip Mine[/autocard] less devastating, particularly if they are running [autocard]Crucible of Worlds[/autocard] with it.

2. Legacy/EDH: Whatever your most KEY color fixing land is: A Filter Land, a Shock Land, [autocard]Reflecting Pool[/autocard], a Vivid Land, City of Brass: Not as many "Combos" in Legacy based off of a Single Land being absolutely balls-to-the-walls BAHROHKAHN, but [autocard]Wasteland[/autocard] is still around for everyone not running [autocard]Blood Moon[/autocard], and this card would be good because it's good against Wasteland even though it 'dies' to Blood Moon. Doesn't stop everything like [autocard]Anathemancer[/autocard], but stops SOME of the LD bleeding, like [autocard]Armageddon[/autocard], [autocard]Jokulhaups[/autocard], that-kinda-stuff, and attacking your opponents' lands is so good that every card that protects lands, even if it's not "Auto-4-of", IS "Auto-Narrowly-Useful". 

3. Modern: [autocard]Dark Depths[/autocard]? [autocard]Thespian's Stage[/autocard]? Would combos like this be less ban-worthy if LD playability was increased and consequently the idea of a Land Enchantment protection was less laughable? Picture a different format than we see today, one where something close to [autocard]Pillage[/autocard] might be heavily played? Oh Yeah. And [autocard]Inkmoth Nexus[/autocard], [autocard]Mishra's Factory[/autocard] (if they changed their minds about Duel Decks' general card legality state? but then further started with just a [autocard]Demonic Tutor[/autocard] Ban from the cards affected??)

4. Standard, or any FNM Format, or any Pizza Night Magic at any given time with untuned decks: Man Lands, from Zendikar Duals to [autocard]Mutavault[/autocard], AND even the Xth Edition ones that are less highly praised but still often used for the heck of it.

(I named cards whose interaction with Consecrate Land seemed to me to resemble about the Power Level of the Play that could make an impact there- in some cases I imagined an Alternate Universe of the Format where the cardpools were different than they actually are, but the average "Turn Clock" Power Level of the format was somewhere close to the ballpark of the real world. EVERY single one of these uses is very relevant in Loose EDH, some of these are less feasible to imagine in Higher Powered Formats, like the Man-Duals, but would certainly matter somewhere, like imagine if Man-Duals and this co-existed in Standard: Not good enough for Modern I think, but good enough for Standard Fo Show.)

The basic one-sentence evaluation is that it's a much MUCH Spikier, Narrower, Techier [autocard]Terra Eternal[/autocard]. Being more castable probably counts more in the long run than not protecting every single one of your lands does, *particularly* for those Vintage Combos. This card probably make Strip Mine and Wasteland fairer to have 4 of either in Vintage-with-Friends (Vintage where everyone has to sideboard against Dredge is different). 259: Mesa Pegasus.author: tavaritz
259: Mesa Pegasus.text_parsed:
Yes, but those non-flyers are not riders, but ground support and thus your band can be blocked by non-flyers.

Never understood what was the problem with banding. I just think that they couldn't get it right for computers. Banding had three rules:

1. Only one non-banding per attack group.
2. Attacking group is blocked as one and can be blocked by any that can block one in the group.
3. Player who had banding creature attacking or blocking gets to distribute the incoming damage.

It was the 'band with others' that got the situation confusing.

All these creatures that give their P/T as +P/+T to attacking or blocking creature when tapped don't work like band. First of all banding is commitment that is done before blockers are announced when the bonus giving is normally done after. Secondly only with a bander gets the defender say how to distribute the damage.

But on the other hand, concerning this card: Evasion & banding don't mix very well.
259: Mesa Pegasus.text_posted:

3. Player who had banding creature attacking or blocking gets to distribute the incoming damage.

All these creatures that give their P/T as +P/+T to attacking or blocking creature when tapped don't work like band. First of all banding is commitment that is done before blockers are announced when the bonus giving is normally done after. Secondly only with a bander gets the defender say how to distribute the damage.

But on the other hand, concerning this card: Evasion & banding don't mix very well.

266: Reverse Damage.author: Aquillion
266: Reverse Damage.text_parsed:
Odd. The errata changes the card's effect dramatically. Under modern rules, the original card wouldn't save your life if you took lethal damage, because you'd drop below 0 (and die as a state-based action) before you could cast it. On the other hand, with the original wording, if you took damage from a source multiple times in one turn, Reverse Damage would reverse all of it; the Oracle text doesn't allow that.

Presumably they changed it to prevent the damage because of the rules change that made dying a state-based action; previously you'd only die at the end of the phase, so it could save you if you dropped into negatives. But that doesn't explain why it's no longer capable of reversing damage retroactively when you've been damaged multiple times by the same source -- or why Reverse Polarity, which had nearly identical wording to this originally, has an Oracle text that goes the other way (failing to save you from lethal damage, but allowing you to reverse damage retroactively and to cover something that has damaged you multiple times in one turn.)
266: Reverse Damage.text_posted:
Odd.  The errata changes the card's effect dramatically.  Under modern rules, the original card wouldn't save your life if you took lethal damage, because you'd drop below 0 (and die as a state-based action) before you could cast it.  On the other hand, with the original wording, if you took damage from a source multiple times in one turn, Reverse Damage would reverse all of it; the Oracle text doesn't allow that.

Presumably they changed it to prevent the damage because of the rules change that made dying a state-based action; previously you'd only die at the end of the phase, so it could save you if you dropped into negatives.  But that doesn't explain why it's no longer capable of reversing damage retroactively when you've been damaged multiple times by the same source -- or why [autocard]Reverse Polarity[/autocard], which had nearly identical wording to this originally, has an Oracle text that goes the other way (failing to save you from lethal damage, but allowing you to reverse damage retroactively and to cover something that has damaged you multiple times in one turn.)

268: Samite Healer.author: FooHunter
268: Samite Healer.text_parsed: I actually enjoyed this card a lot.  I liked to inclue 4 of them whenever I had room.  They had two uses... 1) Early damage and 2) Save a big creature from direct damage.  I won several tournament games with several of these guys doing all the damage.  Why?  Because the bigger creatures kept getting nuked and these were all that was left.  So, each turn I just kept poking away.  When playing against direct damage, if you have a couple creatures out there plus a couple of these, then these have to be nuked first, or your opponent has to pay more to kill the bigger creatures.  Imagine the frustration as your opponent tries to calculate how many mana to use on each creature... will you save this one or that one?  Will you split the differentce and prevent one to each?  Is that a Healing Salve in your hand?  It's highly entertaining!

269: Savannah Lions.author: Equinox523
269: Savannah Lions.text_parsed:
Rather than state the obvious and talk about Elite Vanguard, I'll instead talk about the importance of this creature to white's color identity. From the beginning, RIchard Garfield seems to have had it in his mind to give white quality creatures that were slightly ahead of the curve. If you look at Alpha, you had this and Tundra Wolves, both superior to 1-drops in many other colors. White Knight was superior to Grizzly Bears in combat, much like Serra Angel was better than Air Elemental. I love that this continues to be true in modern Magic, with cards like Steppe Lynx and Loam Lion existing. Come to think of it, maybe they are also cats as an homage to this card.

It speaks to the power of this enduring archetype that so many years later, it could still be printed and still be perfectly playable, soldier or otherwise.

270: Serra Angel.author: FooHunter
270: Serra Angel.text_parsed:
When I opened my first booster pack and found Serra, I fell in love with this game!

Whenever I played her, she became a big target. Protection (white) and counter (blue) type spells were very handy. Spirit Link is a great combo... attack and gain life... then defend and gain life.

My all time favorite deck for Type-I tournaments was White, Red and Blue: Serra, Shivan Dragon, Spirit Link, counter/protection spells, direct damage. And of course dual-lands and the Power-9. It took me years to put that deck together. In the end I was never able to get 4 Shivans, so I used Dragon Whelps to suplement.
270: Serra Angel.text_posted:
When I opened my first booster pack and found Serra, I fell in love with this game!

Whenever I played her, she became a big target.  Protection (white) and counter (blue) type spells were very handy.  Spirit Link is a great combo... attack and gain life... then defend and gain life.

My all time favorite deck for Type-I tournaments was White, Red and Blue:  Serra, Shivan Dragon, Spirit Link, counter/protection spells, direct damage.  And of course dual-lands and the Power-9.  It took me years to put that deck together.  In the end I was never able to get 4 Shivans, so I used Dragon Whelps to suplement.

270: Serra Angel.author: Kirbster
270: Serra Angel.text_parsed:
Apparently, Richard Garfield originally intended for the Serra Angel to have Sawblade-like appendages. (Hence, the "Serra" prefix, as in "serrated.")

This was never communicated to Douglas Schuler, however, so the saw-arms were (thankfully) omitted.

There. Now don't say I never teach you anything.
270: Serra Angel.text_posted:

There. Now don't say I never teach you anything.

Everyone else: vote for any comment that demands a Serra, planeswalker.

280: Bayou.author: achilleselbow
280: Bayou.text_parsed: I think that's the key to understanding why these were printed the way they were and apparently not considred overpowered at the time. Considering how many pure color-hate cards there were in early magic sets (Karma, Angry Mob, Curse of Marit Lage, Wrath of Marit Lage, Flashfires, etc), counting as two land types was thought to be enough of a disadvantage to balance out the convenience. They even go out of their way to underline this in the rules text.  Nowadays, Wizards thankfully doesn't print such cheap boring cards as the aforementioned anymore, and there are many more cards that derive positive effects from you controlling certain land types.
280: Bayou.text_posted: I think that's the key to understanding why these were printed the way they were and apparently not considred overpowered at the time. 280: Bayou.author: DarthParallax
280: Bayou.text_parsed:
Commenting on Every Card this Weekend! Alpha has more great cards than most people realize. It's not just the Power 20 (9 + Duals + Your Favorite Other Card)- MOST of the Rares still hold up to today's measure for uncommons, and even the commons are usually not awful in Limited! And there are lots of nice little pretty gems like Animate Dead :D

I'm going to straight up say and admit that I liked this card a LOT less (flavor wise) before Pirates of the Caribbean.

Also, Innistrad Block happened to remind me a lot of Scooby-Doo on Zombie Island. :3

Since we live in a post-Doom Blade world now, Terror will never be Reprinted for Standard. :P Therefore, here is my Tribute for the forgotten Black Kill Spell :)

You Hear the SCREECHING of an OWL,
You Hear the WIND begin to HOWL--,
You Know there's ZOMBIES on the Prowl!

And it's TERROR TIME AGAIN,
They've got you running Through the NIGHT,
It's TERROR TIME AGAIN,
And you just might DIE OF FRIGHT,
It's a TERRORFYING TIME!,

You Hear the BEATING of your HEART,
You Know the SCREAMING'S gonna start,
Here COMES THE REALLY SCARY PART,

Cause it's TERROR TIME AGAIN,
They've got you RUNNING THROUGH THE NIGHT,
It's TERROR TIME AGAIN,
Oh, you JUST MIGHT DIE OF FRIGHT,
IT'S A TERRORFYING TIME,

All the TREES begin to MOAN,
And the MONSTERS GRUNT and GROAN,
Rotting Faces full of SLIME,
Don't you know it's TERROR TIME?

And it's TERROR TIME AGAIN,
They've got you Running THROUGH THE NIGHT,
Yes, it's TERROR TIME AGAIN,
Oh, YOU JUST MIGHT DIE OF FRIGHT,
It's a TERRORFYING TIME!!!!

29: Living Wall.author: Equinox523
29: Living Wall.text_parsed: Truly grotesque art, but makes a lot of sense. This is actually still not a bad wall, especially considering that -toughness kill spells such as Dismember, which are one of the most common forms of regeneration-hosing out there, cannot kill it alone at a hefty 6 toughness. As a colorless artifact, it can be played in any deck that needs some defense, and at its cost is not too prohibitive in slower formats. This would be a very fair card in limited, because though it can block all day, it will not straight win you games, and without flying it would not solve problems with evasive creatures. It would certainly be cool to see this old card reprinted in the future.

2: Basalt Monolith.author: DarthParallax
2: Basalt Monolith.text_parsed:
Commenting on Every Card this Weekend! ^_^
Alpha has turned out to be a joy to read all over again and comment on. Actually have had something interesting to say on every card so far!


The Comment view is not as good as going back a page to see the Oracle Text for it. Click on it's picture. (Just helping out people that might be VERY new to Gatherer mechanics)
Then you will probably see the loopholes a LOT easier! :D

It´s strange... There are different versions of this card, and somehow, every version says something different on its text, but if you read the text on this version, then it actually should be possible to go infinite with this. However, when I play on ***atrice, the oracle text says, that you can only untap Mana Vault at the beginning of your upkeep, which actually stops you from being able to go infinite, i think, since the beginning of the upkeep already ended, after you untapped it for the first time.

But every other version really still says something else, like only being able untap it during your upkeep, but nothing about only the beginning of upkeep, for example... really weird...

33: Mox Jet.author: scumbling1
33: Mox Jet.text_parsed:
"what was wotc thinking. without the four of rule, (when this was first printed) why would you ever play a land? "

They were thinking that players wouldn't collect the cards so seriously. They knew some cards were much better than the others, but figured that it wouldn't matter because nobody would go out of their way to obtain dozens of them.

I doubt Richard Garfield would have believed it that the game would still be going strong after nearly twenty years.

3: Black Lotus.author: SirDoom
3: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
Saying that Yawgmoth's Will is better than Black Lotus is like saying candy is better than money.

The power 9 are the power 9 for a reason. That reason being that no matter what your combo, no matter what card you want to get to win these will help you.

Yawgmoth's Will is a great card, don't get me wrong. But it is not as universally awesome as the power 9. Black Lotus is the king of them all because it goes in any deck as said above. Of course if you have a Time Walk you might load up whatever mono-deck you have with dual lands just so you can slap it in there anyway, but that's a different discussion...

The only reasonable arguement anyone could make would be Demonic Tutor or similar cards for the same reason.

3: Black Lotus.author: Mode
3: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
Crevette72, at this point where cards are sold for three digits it becomes a bit more than just a game.
You can simply reprint the power nine that easily. If they did it for example as purchasable "From the Vault" set, they would have to decide between two wrong options: Either they sell it for a cheap price and old cards might lose a crucial part of their value, or they had to sell it for an insolently high prince to prevent that.
Even something in between like 300 bugs would be ridiculously cheap in comparison while as a new product with not even a dozen cards as such would be extremely excessive.
It's not that i would not love to see a remake of these cards, but this will at most likely happen in form of priceless promo cards.

3: Black Lotus.author: professornutbutter
3: Black Lotus.text_parsed: I lost my fair share of these beautiful babies when everybody still played for ante. The good news was I could always trade a Shivan Dragon, any of the Moxen, a Time Walk, or even a Serra Angel or Sengir Vampire to get it back. Or, much more commonly, I'd just keep playing games against the player who won one and I'd soon enough win something he wanted back bad enough to trade one for one, like a Force of Nature, Gaia's Leige, or Aspect of Wolf! I remember buying two of them for $4 a piece, and everybody thought I was stone cold nuts for spending "so much" on a single card! :D I miss those simpler days (and ante!) and wish I'd known how much they'd eventually be worth... /tear

Eventually, they may just outright ban them, or allow for proxies in larger tournaments, but they will never, never, reprint these guys. And to the &@$+@^! who remembers them at $4, we don't need people like you driving people like us to make a time machine, go back in time, buy 50 of them and seal them in a case, and shatter the universe.

3: Black Lotus.author: SlackWareWolf
3: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
I'm literally in shock that some of the people posting on here are so stupid... Did they start playing yesterday? We have all been there, wondering why it was so great when it did a little more than an Island, or Plains, but then when you see not only can it add to storm count for free, or better yet, hold in hand for 3 Dark Rituals, and cast them all for free, and just go nuts with whatever you had in hand you start realizing that the reason it costs so much and is so great, is because it adds SPEED. Any game is going to be won faster when someone can pop this and a few Moxes out, and then Tinker for Inkwell Leviathan on turn 0, and still have Mana left to counter something.

And, to the moron who replied to the unlimited version, thanks for the laugh that you'd be able to kill it with Shatter, that was almost as priceless as this card. Moron.

3: Black Lotus.author: MechaKraken
3: Black Lotus.text_parsed:
Black Lotus is certainly powerful, but I think it's power is lessened a bit in EDH/Commander.

Sure, it would be a great draw during the first few turns, but after say, turn 9-10 when you already have most if not all of the mana you'll need for your deck, this card becomes a dead draw. I think the same thing whenever I see someone include Dark Ritual or Lotus Petal in their EDH/Commander decks - risky but worth it if you can draw it during the early game.

It would be a great help if you went against someone playing land destruction, or land tap (telekinetic sliver, opposition, etc) EDH/Commander decks, or if you were playing charged spells that can only get better with more mana (comet storm, banefire), though. Then it wouldn't be so much of a dead draw in the late game (post turn 10). However, by that point there are also better late-game ramp cards (Mirari's Wake, Mana Reflection, etc) so its up to you. Early game advantage or late game staying power?

40: Sol Ring.author: DarthParallax
40: Sol Ring.text_parsed:
One Ring to Rule Them All
One Ring to Find Them
One Ring to Bring Them All
And in the Darkness Bind Them

I will always consider Sol Ring, not Black Lotus, to be the Lord of the Moxen.

Thinking from the perspective of a 'real' Planeswalker, NOT a card game player, Black Lotus has rarity, and potential power, but destroying itself to use is simply not reliable enough to be so coveted. It's a pretty token to distract fools with. If I were Nicol Bolas, I'd much prefer an artifact that allows me to gain mana continuously. Though of course, because of the way the lore translates to the card game, Black Lotus happens to be a hundred times superior

43: The Hive.author: OmegaSerris
43: The Hive.text_parsed:
@Fert12334
That's because this is a 'Mono Artifact' (Look at it's type line). 'Mono' was an old subtype of artifact that inherently required a to use it's ability, so it only had one use per turn (hence the 'Mono'.) Sort of like how the land subtype 'Forest' inherently adds ": Add to your mana pool." to what ever land it's on.

The alternative was 'Poly Artifact' that did not need the and so could be activated multiple times a turn. Pyramids being one of these. And other was 'Continuous Artifact' that needed no activation, but had static or triggered abilities, like Enchantments. One you should be familiar with is Howling Mine, which only recently left Standard. The line on the Mine about only if is untapped on the more recent versions is also something that was part of the Continuous line of artifacts, in that they lost their effect when tapped.

43: The Hive.author: Ryjhan
43: The Hive.text_parsed: To all the people hating on this card as a crappy token generator: You are completely missing the point. This card was the FIRST token generator. All artifacts had inflated casting costs at this time, since there was tons of color hate spells and wotc thought that being able to put something into any deck was a big premium to its value. And in addition, evasion abilities like flying could frequently be game enders. For its time, this card was something to be feared.

45: Time Vault.author: tavaritz
45: Time Vault.text_parsed:
The original wording of Time Vault is:

Tap to gain an additional turn after the current one. Time Vault doesn't untap normally during untap phase; to untap it, you must skip a turn. Time Vault begins tapped.

It clearly states that you must skip a turn to untap Time Vault.

Why not word it so that no other untapping won't work. This is my take of the Oracle wording:

Time Vault enters the battlefield tapped.
Time Vault doesn't untap unless you skip your turn. (You can only skip your turn when your turn is about to begin.) If you would begin your turn while Time Vault is tapped, you may skip that turn instead. If you do, untap Time Vault.
Tap: Take an extra turn after this one.

48: Animate Dead.author: tavaritz
48: Animate Dead.text_parsed:
@Guest57443454: There is nothing broken with this and Worldgorger Dragon.

When Worldgorger Dragon is in any graveyard and you cast this targetting it, Worldgorger Dragon comes to play with this attached to it as an enchantment. The comes into play ability of Worldgorger Dragon triggers and when it resolves all other permanents you control are exiled. This includes the Animate Dead that is enchanting the Worldgorger Dragon. When that happens Animate Dead's triggered ability goes into stack and when it resolves the Worldgorger Dragon is put into its owners graveyard. This triggers Worldgorger Dragon's second ability and when it resolves all your permanents that the Worldgorger Dragon exiled are returned to the battlefield. Now as a state based effect the Animate Dead finds that it is not enchanting anything and goes to your graveyard. End result is that you hope your other permanents has nifty comes into play or removed from the play abilities.

48: Animate Dead.author: DarthParallax

This card in Alpha is one of the most MAGIC-History Defining cards of all time:

It along with Regrowth first gave us the subtle suggestions to use the Graveyard as a RESOURCE not a Discard Pile. That effects so many things it's insane, and MOST Magic decks nowadays are either Built Around using the Graveyard or Life as a Resource, or IN RESPONSE to decks that do that.

Necropotence and Animate Dead together come very close to straight up Defining what MAGIC is for many people. o.o Those two....and...Lightning Bolt, Serra Angel and Counterspell. Yeah. Pretty much That Is Magic.

Commenting on Every Card in Gatherer this Weekend! :D

By the way-- go through Gatherer and just check out all the Alpha and Beta cards that are LESS than $100-1000, that you'd STILL actually play? There's a lot! Alpha is at least as well put together a set as Tempest :3

Since this card's original printing, there are QUITE a lot more Black tokens to abuse it with, making it....still not as good as Honor of the Pure by a long strecth, but probably better than Crusade if you try to build around it!

I know Red has Spark Elementals and stuff like that frequently enough, but I don't think Red does all that many tokens compared to Black.

Sorin, Lord of Innistrad really likes this card, fyi, as does Garruk, Veil-Cursed.

4: Black Vise.author: Equinox523
4: Black Vise.text_parsed:
For those of you who did not play back when this was in the core set, it's important to know a few things:

- There were not many ways of dealing damage on the first turn. This did so, in potentially any color deck.
- The game was much slower, and land destruction was plentiful and cheap. Strip Mine, Sinkhole and Ice Storm are not easy cards to recover from early in the game. This meant your hand might be close to full often, and you might be taking damage from the vise every turn.
- While White had Disenchant, Red had Shatter, and Green had Crumble, Black had next to no ways to permanently deal with artifacts, and Blue could also have problems with this.
4: Black Vise.text_posted:
For those of you who did not play back when this was in the core set, it's important to know a few things:

- There were not many ways of dealing damage on the first turn.  This did so, in potentially any color deck.
- The game was much slower, and land destruction was plentiful and cheap.  [autocard]Strip Mine[/autocard], [autocard]Sinkhole[/autocard] and [autocard]Ice Storm[/autocard] are not easy cards to recover from early in the game.  This meant your hand might be close to full often, and you might be taking damage from the vise every turn.
- While White had [autocard]Disenchant[/autocard], Red had [autocard]Shatter[/autocard], and Green had [autocard]Crumble[/autocard], Black had next to no ways to permanently deal with artifacts, and Blue could also have problems with this.

56: Deathgrip.author: BastianQoU
56: Deathgrip.text_parsed:
Mono Black Spells capable of countering:
Creatures:
Stromgald Cabal: , Pay 1 life: counter target white spell
Thrull Wizard: : Counter target black spell unless it's controller pays or
Instants:
Withering Boon: As an additional cost to cast WB, pay 3 life. Counter target creature spell.

There are 6 cards capable of countering, and 3 cards.

Ignoring blue, white has the strongest countering, focusing on anything targeting you or something you own. Red follows, mostly countering blue instants. Green mainly just keeps itself from being countered.

And that was my learning experience for the day. Just thought I'd share, if anyone is interested.
